articles.title: What's the best way to detect and destroy drones?
articles.summary: Tech firms are developing more affordable ways to detect and destroy drones.
articles.content:
What's the best way to detect and destroy drones?

5 hours ago Share Save Adrienne Murray Technology reporter Share Save

AFP via Getty Images Denmark has taken measures to curb drone flying

In the northern Danish city of Aalborg, the firm MyDefence makes equipment that jams and repels drones. "We've had a big surge of interest," says chief executive, Dan Hermansen. He says that up until early October his company was mainly dealing with defence firms, but now it has "completely shifted". The small, box-like kit made by MyDefence is mostly used by the military of Nato countries and Ukraine. However lately demand has grown from civilian customers. "It's coming from critical infrastructure," he adds, "from big companies, looking to protect their own assets". The device detects communication between the drone and its pilot, then breaks that connection, explains Mr Hermansen, by emitting a powerful radio signal on the same frequency. Rather than falling out of the sky, the drone is pushed away and has a controlled landing. If it tries to reconnect to a GPS signal, that can be blocked too, he adds. Mr Hermansen reckons that radio frequency jamming works against 80 to 90% of the drones that are flown.

MyDefence MyDefence uses powerful radio waves to jam drone control systems

While forcing an unwanted drone to crash land is a good result, it's essential to be able to detect it first. "The first part is really about identification. And the second part is an interceptor system," explains Kasper Hallenborg, director of The Maersk Mc-Kinney Moller Institute at University of Southern Denmark. Identifying a drone is not so easy, points out Andreas Graae, the head of research at the Institute of Military Technology at the Danish Defence Academy. "[Drones] can be very small or really big, and are often produced from materials like plastic or fabrics that are very hard to detect on a traditional radar," he says. A suite of technologies are under constant development, to help find drones. That includes acoustic sensors that listen for the drone's buzzing; advanced optical cameras, with very high resolution; and increasingly sophisticated tactical radars, which work over longer ranges and can even differentiate between a drone or a bird.

Once detected, a drone needs to be disabled. Electronic jamming, similar to that used by MyDefence has leapt forward, thanks in large part to the war in Ukraine. "[Ukraine's] frontlines are totally jammed," Mr Graae says, which means that drone controllers lose control of their machines. So, Russia and Urkaine have adapted by using drones controlled by fibre optic cables, or using drones that can navigate autonomously, or fly along pre-programmed routes. Such drones need to be intercepted or shot down and plenty of firms are working on novel ways to do that. Among them is Swedish start-up, Nordic Air Defence. It is developing a low-cost interceptor designed to strike the targeted drone, forcing it to crash. "It's missile shaped, so travels incredibly fast," he adds. "It's incredibly easy to manufacture. It is basically 3D printed," says Jens Holzapfel, the company's business director.

AFP via Getty Images Cheap hunter drones are one way to intercept unwanted drones

Cost is a criticial factor in countering drones. Last month, Nato Secretary-General Mark Rutte said: "It's unacceptable to shoot down drones costing one or two thousand dollars with missiles that may cost half a million or even a million dollars." That's been a big lesson from Ukraine, says Mr Graae. "It's become a competition of how cheap you can actually make a drone attack, and how expensive it is to defend against." "As hostile drones become cheaper, it puts pressure on the defender to manufacture low cost products," agrees Mr Holzapfel.

Low-cost drones are increasingly a security issue away from the frontlines of Ukraine. Poland and Romania had their airspace breached by Russian drones; while separate drone incidents were reported, in Norway, Sweden, Lithuania, Romania and most recently at Germany's Munich airport. In Denmark tensions have also run high after a string of mysterious sightings at airports and military installations around the country. That spurred the defence ministry to deploy "several capacities" that can detect, track and jam drones; and last week Sweden announced plans to invest more than $365m (£275m) in anti-drone systems, including measures to jam and shoot them down, as well as the deployment of hunter drones. Mr Holzapfel at Nordic Air Defence currently works with Sweden and its European allies. As well as the military, clients are from law enforcement agencies and security companies. But he also sees civilian sectors like shipping and the oil and offshore industries as potential markets.

AFP via Getty Images Debris from a destroyed drone hit a rooftop in Poland in September

In a civilian setting. simply shooting down a drone might be too risky. "It could be rather dangerous," says Kasper Hallenborg, pointing to the falling parts and potentially flammable fuel. "We saw the impact in Poland," he continues. "That was just drone fragments, which more or less removed the roof of a house." Early detection would help, says Mr Hallenborg: "Then you can probably take it down somewhere it's more safe to do so." At short ranges, shooting out nets to tangle up the drone is another method and cheap lasers are also being developed. There are also safer, so-called soft-kill options, including hacking. "That's a more secure way to neutralize the drone, because then you can actually control the landing," says Mr Graae.
articles.reasoning: The article describes significant technological advancements in affordable and safer drone detection and neutralization systems, which have broad implications for security of critical infrastructure, public safety, and military defense. The development of low-cost, effective counter-drone technologies addresses an escalating global security challenge, with detailed context on methods and impact, making it an inspiring example of innovation with tangible societal benefits.
articles.personality_title: New affordable tools improve detection and safe removal of drones
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Drones are becoming common everywhere, but some fly where they shouldn’t, causing safety and security worries. Detecting and stopping these drones can be hard, especially because many are small and cheap.

**What happened** – A Danish company named MyDefence has created a small device that can find drones and block their signals. This device forces drones to land safely instead of crashing. Demand for this technology has grown beyond the military to companies protecting important buildings and infrastructure. Experts in Denmark also explain that detecting drones uses many tools like special radars, cameras, and sound sensors. Meanwhile, a Swedish startup called Nordic Air Defence is making a fast, low-cost drone interceptor that can crash unwanted drones by hitting them. These new tools are cheaper and safer than older methods, like shooting expensive missiles.

**Impact** – These new technologies make it easier and safer to stop unwanted drones without risking damage or wasting lots of money. For example, shooting down a small drone with a missile that costs hundreds of thousands of dollars is too expensive. Using radio signals to jam drones or catching them with nets or lasers lowers costs and dangers. This is important because drones are now used near airports, military sites, and cities in many countries, creating new security challenges.

**What's next step** – Countries like Sweden are investing millions to improve anti-drone systems, including jamming, shooting down, or capturing drones safely. Companies will continue developing better ways to detect drones early so they can be stopped in safe places. These technologies will also expand beyond the military to industries like shipping and oil, where drone safety is important.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New, affordable technologies are making it easier and safer to detect and stop unwanted drones, helping protect people and important places from drone threats.

articles.title: AI language models killed the Turing test: do we even need a replacement?
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03386-wChatbots now ace the mathematician's famous imitation game, but imitation never equalled intelligence.
articles.content:
The statue of Alan Turing at Bletchley Park, UK.Credit: Steve Meddle/Shutterstock

Today’s best artificial intelligence (AI) models sail through the Turing test, a famous thought experiment that asks whether a computer can pass as a human by interacting via text.

Some see an upgraded test as a necessary benchmark for progress towards artificial general intelligence (AGI) — an ambiguous term used by many technology firms to mean an AI system with the resourcefulness to match any human cognitive ability. But at an event at London’s Royal Society on 2 October, several researchers said that the Turing test should be scrapped altogether, and that developers should instead focus on evaluating AI safety and building specific capabilities that could be of benefit to the public.

“Let’s figure out the kind of AI we want, and test for those things instead,” said Anil Seth, a neuroscientist at the University of Sussex in Brighton, UK. In focusing on “this march towards AGI, I think we’re really limiting our imaginations about what kind of systems we might want — and, more importantly, what kinds of systems we really don’t want — in our society”.

The event was organized to mark the 75-year anniversary of the publication of British mathematician Alan Turing's seminal paper describing the test, which he called the imitation game. Addressing the philosophically gnarly question of whether machines can think1, the test involves a series of short, text-based conversations between a judge and either a human or a computer. To win, the machine must convince the judge that it is human.

ChatGPT broke the Turing test — the race is on for new ways to assess AI

The meeting’s low-hype approach to machine intelligence proved popular. At the oversubscribed event, speaker Gary Marcus was introduced by Peter Gabriel, the frontman of the rock band Genesis, and, as a personal friend of Marcus, Matrix star Laurence Fishburne had a spot in the audience. More than 1,000 people also watched the event online.

“The idea of AGI might not even be the right goal, at least not now,” said Marcus, a neuroscientist at New York University in New York City, during one of the keynote addresses. Some of the best AI models are highly specialized, such as AlphaFold, Google DeepMind’s protein-structure predictor, he said. “It does a single thing. It does not try to write sonnets,” he said.

Beyond Turing

Turing’s playful thought experiment has often been used as a gauge of machine intelligence, but it was never meant as a serious or practical test, said Sarah Dillon, a literature researcher at the University of Cambridge, UK, who studies the mathematician’s works.

Some of today’s most capable AI systems are refined versions of large language models (LLMs) that predict text on the basis of associations made in learning from internet data. In March, researchers tested four chatbots in a version of the Turing test, and found that the best models passed.

Yet the fact that chatbots can imitate speech credibly does not mean that they can understand, said several researchers at the event. Although LLM responses can be uncannily human, “when you go outside the box of what you normally ask of these systems, they have a lot of trouble,” said Marcus. As examples, he cited the inability of some models to label the parts on an elephant correctly, or to draw clock hands in anywhere but the ten and two positions. For this reason, models could still fail the Turing test if they are challenged by a scientist who knows their weaknesses.

AI researcher Gary Marcus (left) with actor Laurence Fishburne at the Turing event.Credit: Courtesy of the Web Science Institute at the University of Southampton

Still, the rapid improvement of LLM-based systems in a broad range of areas, especially reasoning tasks, has prompted speculation about whether machines will soon reach human-level performance on cognitive tests. To chart AI’s growing capabilities, and to capture non-language-based skills, researchers have sought to construct harder tests. One of the most recent is the second version of the puzzle-based Abstract and Reasoning Corpus for AGI (ARC-AGI-2), which is supposed to assess an AI’s ability to adapt efficiently to new problems. Such tests are often framed as milestones on the route to general intelligence, but researchers don’t agree on any one benchmark for achieving AGI.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses a significant shift in AI research focus from passing the Turing test to developing AI systems with practical, safe, and beneficial capabilities for society. It highlights the importance of redefining AI benchmarks to prioritize real-world impact and safety, which is inspiring and meaningful for the broad public given AI's growing influence.
articles.personality_title: Experts call for new AI tests as chatbots pass the Turing test
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Turing test, created by mathematician Alan Turing 75 years ago, is a way to see if a computer can act like a human in text conversations. Passing this test has long been seen as a sign of intelligent machines.

**What happened** – Recently, advanced AI chatbots like ChatGPT have passed the Turing test, convincing people they are human in text chats. However, at a special event in London on October 2, 2025, researchers argued that this test is no longer useful. Instead, they suggest focusing on AI safety and building systems that help people in specific ways.

**Impact** – This is important because passing the Turing test only shows that AI can imitate human conversation, not that it truly understands or thinks like a person. Experts pointed out that many AI models are good at one task but struggle outside their area. Changing how AI is tested could lead to safer and more helpful technologies.

**What's next step** – Researchers are working on new tests that challenge AI to solve different kinds of problems, like puzzles that require reasoning and adapting to new situations. These tests aim to measure real abilities beyond just talking like a human.

**One-sentence takeaway** – As AI chatbots pass the Turing test, experts say it’s time to create better ways to measure AI’s true skills and ensure it benefits society safely.

articles.personality_title_es: Expertos piden nuevas pruebas para la IA tras superar los chatbots el test de Turing
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El test de Turing, creado hace 75 años por el matemático Alan Turing, sirve para comprobar si una computadora puede hacerse pasar por humana en conversaciones escritas. Pasar esta prueba se ha considerado durante mucho tiempo una señal de inteligencia artificial.

**Qué pasó** – Recientemente, chatbots avanzados como ChatGPT han pasado el test de Turing, convenciendo a personas de que son humanos en chats de texto. Sin embargo, en un evento especial en Londres el 2 de octubre de 2025, investigadores dijeron que esta prueba ya no es útil. En su lugar, proponen centrarse en la seguridad de la IA y en crear sistemas que ayuden a las personas en tareas específicas.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque pasar el test de Turing solo muestra que la IA puede imitar la conversación humana, no que realmente entiende o piensa como una persona. Los expertos señalaron que muchos modelos de IA son buenos en una tarea, pero tienen problemas fuera de su área. Cambiar cómo se evalúa la IA podría llevar a tecnologías más seguras y útiles.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores están desarrollando nuevas pruebas que desafían a la IA a resolver diferentes tipos de problemas, como acertijos que requieren razonamiento y adaptación. Estas pruebas buscan medir habilidades reales más allá de solo hablar como un humano.

**Frase clave** – Mientras los chatbots superan el test de Turing, los expertos dicen que es hora de crear mejores formas de medir las verdaderas habilidades de la IA y asegurar que beneficie a la sociedad de forma segura.
